title: What are the functions of the plasma membrane? - Quora

response.answer_text: Plasma membrane or cell membrane is a biological membrane surrounding the cell and composed of the lipid bilayer. It separates the cytosol of the cell from the extracellular space.  Image source[1] What is the plasma membrane? The plasma membrane and associated proteins have many functions- The most basic function of the plasma membrane is to provide a barrier between the intracellular components and extracellular matrix.It has several proteins associated with it which help in signalling.The plasma membrane also has certain transmembrane proteins which act as channels and carrier. These facilitate the movement of ions and molecules across the cell membrane.The plasma membrane is selectively permeable which helps in balancing the concentration of ions (Na[math]^+[/math], K[math]^+[/math]) inside the cytosol. They also help in maintaining the potential difference of the membrane by transporting them inside or outside the cell. Thus, helps in polarization and depolarization of the membrane.Plasma membrane also has certain proteins which link with the cytoskeleton and hence help in maintaining the cell shape and cell integrity. For example, spectrin protein in RBC.The plasma membrane also helps in cell-cell Interaction and help in the formation of junctions such as the tight junction, gap junctions, desmosomes, hemidesmosomes, plasmodesmata etc. The proteins associated with the plasma membrane will facilitate the formation of Junctions. Further readings Korn, E.D., 1968. Structure and function of the plasma membrane: a biochemical perspective. The Journal of general physiology, 52(1), pp.257-278. Watson, H., 2015. Biological membranes. Essays in biochemistry, 59, pp.43-69. Harsh Oza (हर्ष ओज़ा)'s answer to What are lipid rafts? Footnotes[1] Image on mechanobio.info

The main functions of plasma/cell membrane are- Cell membrane gives definite shape to the cell and provides mechanical support.Cell membrane is selectively permeable in nature and maintains unequal distribution of Na+, K+, Ca2+ and Cl- ions across the cell membrane, which plays crucial role in generation of potential difference across the plasma membrane. The inside of cell is negative as compared to out side the cell and , potential difference across the plasma membrane is known as resting membrane potential (RMP), when the cell is in resting state. RMP varies from -70 mV to -90 mV.Membrane bound voltage-gated and receptor-operated ionic channels(Na+, K+ & Ca2+- channels), ionic pumps (Na+, K+-ATPase & Ca2+-ATPase) and ion-exchange systems(e.g. Na+-Ca++ antiport) take part in ion-transport across cell membrane, which plays pivotal role in generation of AP & pacemaker potential, muscle contraction, nerve impulse transmission, excitation-secretion coupling, neurotransmitter release, etc.Cell membrane possesses various plasma membrane bound receptors for the physiological actions of various hormones, neurotransmitters and drugs.Plasma membrane bound G-protein takes part in signal transduction. The cell membrane bound enzymes adenylate cyclase and guanylate cyclase catalyze the production of cyclic nucleotides cAMP and cGMP which serve as ‘second messenger’ and take part in signal transduction.Microvilli of intestinal epithelial cells increase the cellular surface area many folds and take part in absorption of digested food like glucose, amino acids, etc.Different muco/glyco-proteins of membranes of RBCs constitute the blood groups.Active transport of proton (H+) by the cell membrane bound H+-pump (K+-H+-ATPase) of gastric patrietal cells is responsible for production of acid (HCl) in stomach.Membrane bound phospholipase C takes part in calcium-phosphatidyl-inositol system.ENDOCYTOSIS (Phagocytosis & Pinocytosis) is an important function of plasma membrane. Phagocytosis (Greek: cell eating) is a mechanism that enables the cells to engulf the solid particles like bacteria. It is shown by cells of immune system- neutrophils, monocytes and macrophages. Pinocytosis (Greek: cell drinking) is, however, intake of droplets of liquid.EXOCYTOSIS: Cell membrane takes part in secretion of secretory materials like digestive enzymes, hormones, plasma proteins, immunoglobulins, etc. and excretion of waste products out side the cell.Ref: Textbook of Biochemistry with Biomedical Significance by Prem Prakash Gupta, CBS Publishers New Delhi, second edition

Plasma membrane- It is a network of lipids and proteins that forms the boundary between a cell's content and outside of the cell. It is simply know as cell membrane. Now coming to the functions of the plasma membrane: One of the important function of plasma membrane is 1. Physical barrier: the plasma membrane surrounds the cell and separates the cytoplasm, from the extracellular fluid outside the cell. Thus protecting the components of the cell from the outside environment. 2. Selective permeability: plasma membranes are selectively permeable. Meaning that only certain molecules can pass through them. Like water, oxygen, carbon dioxide. 3. Endocytosis and exocytosis: Endocytosis is when a cell ingests relatively larger contents than the single ions or molecules that pass through channels. Through endocytosis, a cell can take in large quantities of molecules. Exocytosis is when the cell releases these materials. The cell membrane plays an important role in both of these processes. The shape of the membrane itself changes to allow molecules to enter or exit the cell. 4. Cell signalling: another important function of plasma membrane is communication and signalling it does so by the use of various proteins and carbohydrates.

It provides a selective membrane which acts as a barrier to the environment. The membrane prevents potentially harmful ions from freely diffusing into the cell while still allowing the permeation of nutrients and other essential molecules. It provides structure to the cell by virtue of its phospholipid bilayer structure which is hydrophobic therefore it keeps the internal environment of the cell intact because the cytoplasm is polar and will not leak through the membrane. It is important in motility as the cell can move by attaching microtubules to the membrane and then geometrically transform itself to move in different directions. The fact that receptor proteins can be embedded in the membrane such as ion gated channel proteins make the plasma membrane absolutely essential for cell signalling. In addition, it allows cells to receive chemical signals in the form of steroids as these are lipids which can pass through the phospholipid bilayer since they are nonpolar.

The function of the plasma membrane is to protect the inner components and organelles, from the outside environment. Other functions include allowing nutrients and waste products to enter into and out of the cell, usually by excretion in vesicles produced in the Golgi Apparatus. The lipid bilayer of phospholipids and protein, help migrate selected molecules into the cell, the nuclear envelope of the cell is semi-permeable. They also function in maintaining the structure and support of the cell.

THREE MAIN FUNCTIONS OF PLASMA MEMBRANE; The regulation and control of the entry of metabolic reactant materials and nutrients, and the exit of metabolic/cell wastes.The protein pore channels ( present in the membrane ), are responsible for the transfer of mineral ions, across the fluid mosaic membrane, utilising energy during the process of active transport.The changing of shape required during the locomotive processes of the cell membrane ( only applicable if the cell is unicellular ). An example of this can be seen in the movement of paramoecium.

Plasma membranes are protective covering around cell and many cell organelles like nucleus, mitochondria ,chloroplast etc Plasma membranes are important because they allow only certain substances to pass into or out of the cell or organelle so that only the substances needed can enter or leave the cell Plasma membrane is also called as cell membrane or cell surface membrane (if around cell) It is called as nuclear membrane if it is present around nucleus . And it may have other names according to structure around it is present .

In addition to the useful answers already provided, I'd like to emphasize a role of the cell membrane I think is especially cool: It holds receptors in place that allow cells to communicate with each other.  In particular, proteins such as cytokines, secreted by certain cells, may bind to receptor proteins held in membranes of certain other cells.  That binding may cause the receptor protein to change its shape, initiating a cascade of phosphorylations along a chain of intracellular molecules  that leads into its nucleus, and causes its DNA to react. That's one of the most important functions in biology.  Just one fine example is that it can activate stem cells to replenish your blood.  We couldn't live and grow without that function, and the others, of the cell's membrane. It's things like that that make biology a study of awesomeness.

The main function of the plasma membrane is to partially isolate the inside of a cell from the outside, so that the composition inside the cell can be different from its environment. The content of ions (pH), enzimes and other proteins is tightly regulated inside a cell, and this wouldn't be posible without a selectively permeable membrane to the outiside. Appart from this, another basic function of the plama membrane is to contain all the organelles, nucleus and other components within a close range so they can interact in the various metabolic pathways and processes that keep a cell alive.

A plasma membrane is a semi-permeable membrane that surrounds the cell, and keeps the cytoplasm and cell organelles inside.  Various structures embedded in the plasma membrane control diffusion of chemicals across the membrane and communication with other cells.Cell membrane

I'm not sure what experience level you are coming at this question from, but in the most general sense, a plasma membrane is the barrier between a cell and its outside environment. It functions to: Regulate the entry and exit of molecules through 1) embedded protein channels and 2) it's semi-permeable membrane structure.Provide structure to a cell. In some organisms, it is the base from which the cytoskeleton or cell wall is anchored to. Communicate with other cells & the outside environment (by way of surface protein markers).There is much more to be said about the plasma membrane and many accessible sources to help you out. See: Structure of the Plasma Membrane, Function of Plasma Membrane, Cell Membrane Function

The cell membranes cause compartmentalisation. As plasma membranes separate the cells from their external environment. As organelle coverings, they allow the cells organelles to maintain their identity, internal environment and functional individuality. Plasma membrane protects the cell from injury. The membranes allow the flow of materials and information between different organelles of the same cell as well as between one cell and another. As plasmodesmata and gap junctions the biomembranes provide organic connections between adjacent cells.

Plasma membranes have three primary functions: (1) they keep toxic substances out of the cell; (2) they contain receptors and channels that allow specific molecules, such as ions, nutrients, wastes, and metabolic products, that mediate cellular and extracellular activities to pass between organelles and between the cell and the outside environment; and (3) they separate vital but incompatible metabolic processes conducted within organelles.

Plasma membrane has many vital functions in life… Plasma membrane allow selective molecules and ions to pass across it due to which cell is prevented by chemical stress which can be lead to cell death. Plasma membrane also enclose cytoplasm. Plasma membrane is involved in endocytosis(eating process of cell).vacuole forming in animal cell. Plasma membrane in cell also transport proteins in extracellular environment. It also cause nerve impulse to travel in case of nerve cell. In bacteria it is involved in the formation of mesosome.

Plasma or cell membrane is the cover of cells that protects cytoplasm from outer surroundings. It is a combination of proteins and lipids that makes the boundary of the cell. Because it is partly pervious, it controls the material flow to and from the cells. It is one of the primary functions of plasma membrane to provide such control, for example, allowing water but regulating ions. Endocytosis and Exocytosis, transmitting signals among cells, containment and control of carbs and proteins are additional important functions of plasma (cell) membrane.

Basically, membranes in general have two functions: Keeping stuff like organelles together so that they can work together and so that they have access to the nutrients they need. Ribosomes can't make proteins very well if they don't have a mitochondrion nearby to make ATP.Only letting in the good stuff. This way, the cell can avoid toxins (ideally) and get useful things like oxygen.

Interestingly, the ability of the plasma membrane to act as a barrier for the transport of molecules enables the cell to generate and store energy. The cell uses energy to generate a gradient of sodium and potassium that the cell can later use to transport other molecules (this is called secondary active transport).

Protection of internal organelles, regulating internal cell pressure, control of the entry/exit of molecules into the cell, and to provide binding sites for ligands that initiate/terminate internal cell functions.

It provides a definite structure to the cell and holds all cellular organelles and other cellular matter inside it. Also it helps in other life processes like osmosis and active transport of ions and other matter to and from the cell Hope this helps😁

The function of plasma membrane is selectively allowing the particles to pass through. Hence it is called as selectively permeable membrane. It encloses all the organelles of a cell.It is made up of proteins and lipids.Without plasma membrane a cell won't survive.

The main purpose of the plasma membrane is to control what goes in and out of the cell. Through the processes of diffusion, facilitatee diffusion, osmosis and active Transport, it regulates the molecules that enter and leave the cell

The ONE function of the cell membrane is to control movement of charged and polar ions and molecules in or out of cells. Transport channels (protein) allow charged and polar substances in and out the cells in a selective manner. For example GLUT channels are regulated by various ligands including insulin, Na, K or Ca. Once opened the GLUT will admit glucose into the cells but once glucose is phosphorylated to glucose 6 phosphate (first reaction of glycolysis) it cannot leave the cell.
